author: @ShortClipsPodcasts
text: anyone stuck trying to get the price.      price_symbol = soup2.find(class_='a-price-symbol').get_text(strip=True) price_whole = soup2.find(class_='a-price-whole').get_text(strip=True) price_fraction = soup2.find(class_='a-price-fraction').get_text(strip=True) price = f'{price_symbol}{price_whole}{price_fraction}'    print(price)

author: @nevinphilbert
text: man i've been battling with the bot blocker from amazon and also some scraping issues with price because the website display was changed a while after this video was uploaded, but I've managed to pull it off so i hope this might help those recent viewers who might be as confused as me when I started writing this code on my own.  apparently you need to divide the second cell so you need to run the soup1 first before you run the soup2, then for the price you need to pull three part of span class=a-price-symbol, span class=a-price-whole, and span class=a-price-fraction and combine it together into 1 new variable (price), then you need to clean it using strip() and replace() to clean the whitespaces and \n's.  hope this helps!

author: @danweinstein4695
text: How I got soup2 to work  I assume the price element on the html code changed for the webpage. The one I found on my page was id="corePriceDisplay_desktop_feature_div"  The price came out formatted a little differently so I fixed it. Heres the code I used  soup2.find(id="corePriceDisplay_desktop_feature_div").get_text()  price1 = price[price.index("$"):(price.index("$")) + 6]  Hope this works

author: @newyork397
text: As others described, if you get an error when running the second cell it's probably due to a captcha issue where amazon thinks you are a bot. You can force it by pressing ctrl + enter again and again until you get an output. I'm sure there is a better way to get around this but that's the quickest semi solution I found.

text: It works once and then stops working. Amazon is blocking the request I think. The id's are correct. It does not change if you use lxml, html.parser, or html5lib. So basically amazon doesn't let you scrape their website

author: @jucajata95
text: A solution for the problem of the price and various prices:  price = soup2.find(id='priceblock_ourprice') or "abc" price = price.get_text() price = price.split() prices = []  for p in price:     try:         a = float(p)         prices.append(a)     except:         continue prices

author: @horacezhen
text: Hi Alex. I love this so much. In the past I've tried to scrape all the product from the Amazon keyword search page as well as the best seller rank pages. I think we can perform some analysis in regards of product prices, market landscape, sales volume, and etc. However, I have triggered Amazon's alert and it says they classified my ip as scraping data from Amazon and blocks me out. Is there a way that we can pull product details data for every single product after we scraped 100 product links from the Amazon's best seller rank page? I hope that this would already be covered in your upcoming videos!
